content: An Armenian-American group that backed Barack Obama in the election is now urging its members to call the White House to protest the president’s failure to recognize the “Armenian genocide.” As many as 1.5 million Armenians living within the Ottoman Empire perished beginning in 1915 as the Turks fought World War 1. Armenians and most historians regard the deaths as state-sponsored mass killings, or genocide, while Turkey insists the death were the result of a civil war coupled with disease and famine. During his presidential campaign, Obama pledged to recognize the deaths as genocide. He spoke in a January 2008 statement of his “firmly held conviction that the Armenian genocide is not an allegation, a personal opinion or a point of view, but rather a widely documented fact supported by an overwhelming body of historical evidence.” The Washington, D.C.-based Armenian National Committee of America endorsed Obama, delivering large blocs of votes in swing states and tens of thousands of dollars in campaign donations, according to Politico.com. But at a Monday press conference with Turkish President Abdullah Gul and in a later address to the Turkish Parliament, Obama declined to recognize the Armenian deaths as genocide. Obama “missed a valuable opportunity to honor his public pledge to recognize the Armenian genocide,” Aram Hamparian, executive director of the Armenian National Committee, said in a statement. In his address to parliament, Obama did refer to the “terrible events of 1915” and said “the best way forward for the Turkish and Armenian people is a process that works through the past in a way that is honest, open and constructive.” When asked by a reporter if he had encouraged President Gul “to recognize the genocide by name,” Obama did not answer directly and instead praised Gul for taking part in “a series of negotiations … between Armenia and Turkey to resolve a whole host of longstanding issues, including this one.” Rest here: "http://www.newsmax.com/insidecover/obama_armenians/2009/04/07/200573.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

In his address to parliament, Obama did refer to the “terrible events of 1915” and said “the best way forward for the Turkish and Armenian people is a process that works through the past in a way that is honest, open and constructive.” When asked by a reporter if he had encouraged President Gul “to recognize the genocide by name,” Obama did not answer directly and instead praised Gul for taking part in “a series of negotiations … between Armenia and Turkey to resolve a whole host of longstanding issues, including this one.” Rest here: "http://www.newsmax.com/insidecover/obama_armenians/2009/04/07/200573.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
title: Armenians Blast Obama for Failure to State Genocide

Armenians Blast Obama for Failure to State Genocide

content: The statement “Well, my views are on the record and I have not changed views,” is enough in this situation. Anyone who expected more from him (while standing next to Turkey's prime minister) is just fooling themselves. I don't understand why anyone would have expected him to do that in Turkey. Oh yes - he ducked it as much as he could. But - he's already on record for calling the events of 1915 genocide, and everyone knows that. So, what was the point of putting him on the spot in Turkey like that? It would have likely caused an international incident, and who other than opponents of Obama or the US would have benefitted from that? What's funny is that a reporter from the Chicago Tribune asked him the question! But, I'm not surprised that an American asked it; we seem to have developed a taste for "gotcha" journalism over the years. We prefer the sensational over the substantive; look at the major news broadcasts.

content: This is not the Turkey of Attaturk or even the Turkey of the early 1990s that I knew. Last year three Christians were murdered for daring to print Bibles. Bringing them to justice has been deliberately delayed. The islamic influence has grown substantially. Obama did not even invite the leader of the Greek Orthodox church, essentially under house arrest in Turkey, to functions while there. Obama was treading real, real light. And that is not the way to impress most of the world, if one is to have influence on their substantive international activities.

content: Personally while I agree with McGreer that this was not the time to speak about the mass murder of Armenians, Obama should indeed officially put us on record... Saying all that, I wonder why all those knocking Obama, whose been in office less than three months, didn't bother to critique Mr. Bush over the issue. Dave
